user.biography: Where great art and courageous conversations are catalysts for a more connected, civic, and empathetic world. We stand with Black Lives Matter.

node.text:
If this past year taught us anything it's that we can accomplish so much more through collaboration with our neighbors and partners. In the final episode of our #YearattheMuseum series, we reconnected with a few of our recent community-based partners @soulsinfocus, @tcahnyc, @f.o.o.dfoundation, and @grandmashandsinc to ask them how we can continue to show up in the years to come.⁠

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow, ft. @lavalshante, Director of Marketing and @keonnah, Director of DEIA.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Community Partnerships

node.text:
So much happens behind-the-scenes of a Museum, and even more so within a conservation lab. Tune in to our latest video with Lisa Bruno, Carol Lee Shen Chief Conservator, for a peek into how we care for our collections—from reversing outdated treatments to stories behind recent projects and what took place when the Museum shut down due to COVID-19. #AYearattheMuseum

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠

Treatments featured: William Williams, Deborah Hall (1766) ⇨ Cecily Brown (British, born 1969). Triumph of the Vanities II, 2018. Purchase gift of John and Barbara Vogelstein in honor of Anne Pasternak © artist or artist's estate⁠ ⇨ Assyrian reliefs, Neo-Assyrian Period, reign of Ashur-nasir-pal II, circa 883–859 B.C.E. Funding for the conservation of the Assyrian Reliefs was generously provided through a grant from the @bankofamerica Art Conservation Project.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Collection Care

node.text:
The role of a curator is a lot more complex than you may think! Hear from Catherine Futter, our Senior Curator of Decorative Arts, on how she accesses the collection and works collaboratively with nearly every department across the Museum. You’ll also get a peek into our new exhibition Design: 1880 to Now, which highlights some of the most important design movements during that period.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
⁠Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ ⁠#AYearAtTheMuseum⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: ⁠Notes from a Curator⁠

node.text:
What did you miss about museums during shutdown? It's been wonderful to safely welcome visitors back to our galleries, and we thank each and every one of them for taking the time to visit! ⁠
⁠
Now more than ever, the strength of our #BKMMembers community is our greatest asset. We hope you continue your support of the Museum by becoming a Member! We now offer discounted 6-month Memberships—learn more at http://bit.ly/bkmmembers (link in bio).⁠
⁠
Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ #ayearatthemuseum

node.title: It’s so good to see you!

node.text: You're tuned in to Screen Time where today Adama Delphine Fawundu (@adamadelphine) discusses “the cleanse” with curator Carmen Hermo (@chermosa). View the video in full on our plaza as part of our Art on the Stoop #SunsetScreenings series, showing each Wednesday, Thursday, and Sunday through November 8, starting at 5pm. ⁠⠀

node.text: Today artist Liz Johnson Artur (@lizjohnsonartur) joins Drew Sawyer (@drewmsawyer), Phillip Leonian and Edith Rosenbaum Leonian Curator of Photography, for a chat about Artur’s work, AfroRussia which is on view as part of our #SunsetScreenings series. We hope you enjoy this brief chat, and are able to check out AfroRussia outside on the Museum plaza through Sunday, October 11. Head to link in bio to find the series' details and schedule.

node.title: Screen Time with Liz Johnson Artur

node.text:
The Campaign Against Hunger’s (@tcahnyc) mission is to empower our neighbors to live healthier, more productive and self-sufficient lives by increasing access to safe, nutritious food and resources. 60% of the clients they serve are from historically undercounted communities. When you fill out the census, you’re advocating for more federal funding towards organizations like this. Take the time today and complete your census at my2020census.gov. #GetCountedNYC⁠⠀
⁠⠀
And for our community members in need—a friendly reminder that our weekly food distribution with @tcahnyc takes place in our sculpture garden behind the Museum, every Monday at 4pm, on a first-come, first-serve basis. We recommend arriving early to receive a ticket in line. If you have any questions, email us at healthymeals@brooklynmuseum.org.⁠⠀

node.text:
⁠The census determines billions of dollars in funding for our schools, health care, jobs programs, housing, transportation, and so many other vital services. Census numbers in central Brooklyn, Bed-Stuy and Crown Heights are substantially lower than other parts of Brooklyn. We and Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr. (@rcornegyjr) want to change that. Make sure to get counted so we can get a fair share of resources for our community.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Fill out the Census now through September 30 at my2020census.gov and #GetCountedNYC

node.title: Census 2020: Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr.

node.text:
Live from Studio 54: Night Magic, Marlene Veras of @balmirdance is here to  celebrate the art of the hustle. Veras will first be joined by Willie “MB” Estrada (@williembestrada), first generation hustle dancer and author, to speak about the history of “The Hustle”. Then Veras will show you the moves of this iconic dance popularized at Studio 54.

Apologies for our audio difficulties. We hope you still have fun following the moves!

After learning the steps, be sure to purchase your ticket to see #studio54bkm in person. Our galleries open on September 12! Tap link in bio to book your next visit.⁠

node.text:
Join a dynamic group of emerging arts professionals for a series of four workshops, organized and led by interns from our team, and explore how interns can drive the field forward with respect to criminal justice reform, immigrant communities, public health, and more. Head to link in bio to RSVP for the following sessions:⁠
⁠
⚫ Monday, August 2, 12:30–2:30 pm⁠
Explore how cultural institutions can contribute to positive public health initiatives.⁠
⁠
⚫ Tuesday, August 3, 12:30–2:30 pm⁠
Ask how cultural institutions can support those who have been affected by the criminal justice system.⁠
⁠
⚫ Wednesday, August 4, 12:30–2:30 pm⁠
Examine how cultural institutions act as advocates for immigration justice.⁠
⁠
⚫ Thursday, August 5, 12:30–2:30 pm⁠
Explore how cultural institutions can create greater equity and inclusion to address historical barriers to BIPOC individuals. ⁠
⁠
#bkmeducation #bkminterns

node.text: Love Brooklyn, art, and culture? Want to join a dynamic team of mission-driven arts professionals? Brooklyn Museum is hiring for positions in several departments. Head to link in bio to learn more about these openings (and more!) and apply today.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brooklyn Museum in Brooklyn Museum with @johncedmonds, and @uovo.art.

node.text:
📢 Good news! John Edmonds: A Sidelong Glance has been extended through September 26. Take advantage of these extra weeks and catch the first solo museum exhibition of our inaugural UOVO Prize-winning artist, John Edmonds. The show features new and recent photographic portraits and still lives of Central and West African sculptures alongside friends and acquaintances from the Edmonds's creative community in New York.⁠
⁠
John Edmonds (American, born 1989). Two Spirits, 2019. Archival pigment photograph. Courtesy of the artist and Company, New York. © John Edmonds

node.text: Our contest with local scoop shop @thesocialbrooklyn ends today! Comment below with your Brooklyn Museum inspired flavor suggestion or name. Winner(s) will receive two free tickets to KAWS: WHAT PARTY, two pints of your flavor creation, a T-shirt from The Social, a Museum tote bag, and the pride and joy of knowing you helped create a flavor that will be scooped for many years to come!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brooklyn Museum on July 29, 2021. May be an image of furniture.

node.text:
Throughout his twenty-five-year career, @kaws has collaborated with a number of other artists and companies. Through these collaborations, KAWS has been able to expand his practice into other creative industries while also broadening the accessibility—both geographically and financially—of his work. In addition to fashion and toys, KAWS has created furniture with design studio Estudio Campana based in São Paulo, Brazil, incorporating his characters into chairs and sofas.⁠
⁠
See this artwork, and many other collaborations, in #kawsbkm. Visit link in bio for tickets.⁠
⁠
KAWS (American, born 1974). KAWS Chair Pink (Pink BFF PLUSH), 2018. Plush toys, stainless steel, and Cumaru wood. © KAWS. (Photo: Daniel Kukla)

node.text:
Outdoor art-making with @bkmteens returns this week! Join us from 3:30–5 pm on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday for free art-making activities on our plaza. This is a free, drop-in program; supplies may be limited.⁠
⁠
Photo: @kolinmendez

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brooklyn Museum on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 4 people, child, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
Applications are now open for our paid @bkmteens internships! Head to our link in bio to learn more about the following opportunities. Open to all NYC high-school students ages 14–19. ⁠
⁠
⟶ Work-Study: Art & Healing⁠
Explore art, education, and mental health, and work with our teaching artists to assist Gallery/Studio Program art classes.⁠ Applications due September 2.⁠
⁠
⟶ Museum Apprentice Program⁠
Learn about art history, the Museum, and museum education while teaching audiences of all ages.⁠ Applications due September 19.⁠
⁠
⟶ InterseXtions: Gender & Sexuality⁠
Explore gender and sexuality through art and activism, and organize programs for other LGBTQ+ youth.⁠ Applications due October 3.⁠
⁠
⟶ Teen Night Planning Committee⁠
Produce free monthly events for other teens that connect art and social justice.⁠ Applications due October 3.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Brooklyn Museum on July 26, 2021 tagging @thesocialbrooklyn. May be an image of gelato and outdoors.

node.text:
🍦🍦 Calling all ice cream enthusiasts 🍦🍦 We need your help to create a special Brooklyn Museum flavor in collaboration with our newest neighbor, The Social. All you need to do is comment with your flavor suggestion or name on @thesocialbrooklyn latest's post. ⁠
⁠
Winner(s) will receive two free tickets to KAWS: WHAT PARTY, two pints of your flavor creation, a T-shirt from The Social, a Brooklyn Museum tote bag, and the pride and joy of knowing you helped create a flavor that will be scooped for many years to come! Plus, a portion of the flavor’s proceeds will be donated to our educational programming.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brooklyn Museum on July 26, 2021. May be an image of child and outdoors.

node.text:
Get your family's creativity flowing on Friday, July 30 from 3–5 pm with our @bkmteens and our partners at Brooklyn Cultural Adventures Program (BCAP) as we explore art from around the world. Make your mark with sidewalk chalk or create your own watercolor ice-cube art, the perfect way to cool off on a summer day. Registered families also get a free activity kit to take home, which includes materials to make zines, a scavenger hunt, a family pass to the Museum, and more! Visit link in bio to RSVP your family.⁠
⁠
Photo: Kolin Mendez

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brooklyn Museum on July 25, 2021.

node.text: Learn about the varied ways works of art move from their communities of origin into museum collections in a two-day virtual teacher workshop on July 27 and 28. We'll explore case studies from our Arts of Africa collection and develop teaching strategies that connect objects and their histories of ownership to engage students with issues of cultural exchange and power. Visit link in bio for tickets and to learn more.

node.text:
Stop by our @brooklyn.pop.up market tomorrow, July 25, from 10:30am–5:30pm to shop handmade items from more than twenty local artisans offering artwork, jewelry, fashion, home and apothecary goods, and more.⁠
⁠
Photo by @kolinmendez
